qas.question: Which cameras were first of their type to adopt the ASA scale?

answers.text: The Weston Cadet (model 852 introduced in 1949), Direct Reading (model 853 introduced 1954) and Master III (models 737 and S141.3 introduced in 1956)

qas.question: What were updated Weston values based on?
How were Weston values changed to ASA values?
Beginning with which year was the Weston to ASA conversion not necessary?
Until what year did other models use the original Weston scale?
Which two models were introduced in 1949?
When did models move back to the Weston scale?
What was added to convert Weston values to the older meters?
What was necessary on meters manufactured after 1956?
When was the ASA scale established?

context: <a0_0>The Weston Cadet (model 852 introduced in 1949), Direct Reading (model 853 introduced 1954) and Master III (models <b5_0>737 and S141.3<b5_0/> introduced in 1956)<a0_0/> were the first in their line of exposure meters to switch and utilize the meanwhile established ASA scale instead. Other models used the original Weston scale up until <b9_0>ca. <a4_0><b6_0>1955<b9_0/><b6_0/><a4_0/>. The company continued to publish Weston film ratings after 1955, but while their recommended values often differed slightly from the ASA film speeds found on film boxes, these newer Weston values were based on <a1_0>the ASA system<a1_0/> and had to be converted for use with older Weston meters <a2_0>by subtracting <b7_0>1/3 exposure stop<b7_0/><a2_0/> as per Weston's recommendation. Vice versa, "old" Weston film speed ratings could be converted into "new" Westons and the ASA scale by adding the same amount, that is, a film rating of 100 Weston (up to 1955) corresponded with 125 ASA (as per ASA PH2.5-1954 and before). This <b8_0>conversion<b8_0/> was not necessary on Weston meters manufactured and Weston film ratings published since <a3_0>1956<a3_0/> due to their inherent use of the ASA system; however the changes of the ASA PH2.5-1960 revision may be taken into account when comparing with newer ASA or ISO values.
